subject: RE: [junit]
msgSnippet: I agree with Hugo...additionally I create a JUnit Execution by copying the External Execution type (Project - Settings - Execution Types). In the Junit
messageBody:
I agree with Hugo...additionally I create a JUnit Execution by copying the
External Execution type (Project - Settings - Execution Types).
In the Junit Execution type set leave the process as
{java.home}{/}bin{/}java

set the Aruguments to:
-cp {filesystems}{:}{classpath}{:}{library} junit.ui.TestRunner {classname}
{arguments}


Then you can set the exeuction type of your TestCase template to use the
Junit Execution type.

With this set up whenever you are editing a TestCase you can just hit F6 to
execute the class and JUnit will pop up.


-----Original Message-----
From: Hugo Garcia [mailto:elhugonyc@...]
Sent: Monday, March 26, 2001 8:36 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit]



I think the simples and fastest way is to :

1) Add the junit.jar to your filesystem.
2) Create a new template for a subclass of TestCase by copying the Main
Class
Template and pasting it in the template with a new name such as TestClass.
3) Modify the template. Mine is shown below.

-H

/*
* __NAME__.java
*
* Created on __DATE__, __TIME__
*/

package Templates.Classes;

/**
*
* @author __USER__
* @version
*/
public class ClassTest extends junit.framework.TestCase {

/** Creates new __NAME__ */
public ClassTest(java.lang.String testName) {
super(testName);
}

/**
* @param args the command line arguments
*/
public static void main(String[] args) {
junit.swingui.TestRunner.main(new String[]
{__NAME__.class.getName()});
}

}


--- rejith <rejith_mn@...> wrote:
> Hi Everybody,
>

>
> Regards
> Rejith
